title: Battered WTO looks to pick itself up off the canvas
text:
“The Americans used to be one of our strongest supporters. Trump’s approach has been a real shock to the system,” says one official.

Trump seems hell-bent on putting the WTO’s appeals body – the enforcer of dispute settlements, which gives the organisation its teeth – into an induced coma. He’s taken his beef with China directly to Beijing, in effect sidelining the WTO as the arbiter of trade grievances. And he’s slapping tariffs on countries using a WTO procedure meant for times of war.

If the rules are being deliberately broken, what happens to the body that makes the rules?

“This is an existential attack on the WTO,” former Mexican president Ernesto Zedillo fulminated during one forum meeting in Geneva.

The World Trade Organisation is said to be facing an existential threat. Getty

“The first decisive battle to prove that we care about the multilateral system will have to be fought in this house. Let us not allow the United States to destroy the WTO!” The room burst into applause.

The fierce battle between Washington and Beijing is the main conflagration in Trump’s trade wars, so it’s easy to overlook the fact that the WTO is fighting fires on many other fronts too.

The damage from this to businesses large and small is slower and more insidious than from the stoush with Beijing. A gradual return to the law of the jungle would end up raising barriers and costs to any company with a stake in the global economy. And the WTO can’t play fireman in the world trade system while it’s getting burnt itself.

Advertisement

Trading blows

Trump – and to be fair, many WTO forum participants – see a different bogyman. In his view, it is China that is flouting the rules, not the US. It has kept its classification as a developing country, which affords concessional treatment on trade barriers. And the WTO sits limply by while China subsidises its state-owned enterprises and forces foreign investors to hand over technology.

As far as he's concerned, if the WTO isn’t with him, it’s against him. The WTO has gone from being an umpire to a target. And this has put the organisation very much on the defensive.

Change is needed ... WTO director-general Roberto Azevedo at the public forum. Keystone

“The overwhelming majority of members, not all, recognise the importance of the system. But there are growing voices saying the system is not perfect. It needs to change, it needs to update itself to face the realities of the 21st century,” admits WTO director-general Roberto Azevedo.

There are a host of separate issues that Trump has kicked into the limelight. The first, and most urgent, is the imminent demise of the Appellate Body, the WTO’s appeals tribunal. The US has been vetoing the appointment of new judges, shrinking the bench to just three members. It takes three to make a quorum, and the terms of two of the judges expire on December 16. If the clock runs down, the court stops working.

Zedillo described the US actions as “a vicious attack” that “if not properly addressed within the next few weeks will take the organisation to the point of practical irrelevance”.

Advertisement

Trump has sometimes made out that his main complaint is simply that the Appellate Body doesn’t always bend to America’s will. But more level heads acknowledge that the US does have specific gripes – and has nurtured them since well before Trump took office. The chief one is that the Appellate Body has styled itself into a proper court, generating case law and precedent. And it has overreached, and it has become unwieldy.

How to fix it? The Americans just aren’t engaging with any of the attempts, including by Australia, to find a solution. There are ideas for ad-hoc arbitration to replace appeals, but this wouldn’t have the sharp teeth of the dispute settlement system.

Some wonder whether it might be possible to change the way it operates, change the legalistic culture that has developed. But there’s no concrete proposal, and very little time.

Weaponising economics

The second issue that’s furrowing brows at the WTO is Trump’s use of a national security clause to levy tariffs on products like steel and aluminium – and possibly, in future, cars.

“Traditionally we think of the WTO as dealing with economic and commercial questions. For security and political matters we have the UN. The WTO is supposed to depoliticise,” says Joost Pauwelyn, a professor of law at the Graduate Institute of International and Development Studies in Geneva.

“Today security and economic issues have joined and people are talking about a new geo-economic order. If you asked President Trump he would say the two are completely intertwined … they are weaponising economic policy.”

Advertisement

The US looks set to stand its ground, and former Costa Rican trade minister Anabel Gonzalez doesn't like what she sees.

“If one country uses the security exemption to roll back its commitments, others will maybe follow and the system would quickly unravel," she says.

Seeing red on China

Then there is the spillover from Trump’s trade war with China. Trump, in a complaint recently echoed by Prime Minister Scott Morrison, is bothered by China’s status as a developing country in the WTO. He says it’s unfair, allowing a rich G20 nation access to trade concessions that should be available only to genuinely poor and vulnerable countries.

But China won’t give up the developing-country tag easily. It sees itself as a leader of the developing world.

“The developing country hat is very dear. It’s political. Xi Jinping said we are a developing country now and for the foreseeable future,” says Lu Xiankun, a Geneva-based trade expert.

Geneva officials reckon there’s a way out of this one. In the Trade Facilitation Agreement of 2017, India, Brazil and China voluntarily renounced the “special consideration” they’d normally get as developing countries. There are other non-plenary initiatives of this kind on the go now where China will likely again not get special and differential treatment.

Advertisement

Trump is also irate that China can subsidise its state-owned enterprises and can force technology transfer from foreign companies to Chinese ones. And he is frustrated that the WTO won’t take action.

“China’s economic system has evolved in profoundly problematic ways that the WTO rule book can’t always address. Chinese officials are really ingenious in exploiting loopholes and weaknesses,” says Paul Blustein, author of the recent book Schism: China, America and the Fracturing of the Global Trading System.

The trouble is that it’s hard to get the evidence, and mounting a challenging takes a long time. Even if the West wins at the WTO, the Chinese companies may already have grabbed a dominant market position.

Blustein reckons a coalition of countries should still try to bring a case against China, using a broad provision called "nullification and impairment", even though no specific rule has been broken. He says China will be more likely to make concessions in the context of a WTO case than in response to Trump’s threats.

“The WTO should be the chief policy instrument for dealing with China. The WTO’s authority should be nurtured to the maximum extent," he says – but instead, Trump is undermining the organisation.

Australia's role

One of the charges the US levels at the WTO is that it’s not delivering anything. The only major negotiation under way is on ending fisheries subsidies, and that is mired over an argument about who should chair the negotiations.

The less heralded bad boys of the WTO, India and South Africa, repeatedly use the consensus system to stymie progress.

Advertisement

That, along with the issue of China’s developing country status and its economic iconoclasm, is pushing the drive towards “plurilateralism”: a bunch of countries coming together to strike a deal on an issue, bypassing the gridlock of the main arena.

Australia has initiated talks on e-commerce involving 80 nations, including China and the US, which is aiming to put an agreement on the table by mid-2020. It's not a WTO negotiation, but is taking place in the building. There are also plurilateral discussions on investment facilitation, domestic services regulation, and on supporting small to medium enterprises.

The move to revive the WTO through energising the plurilateral track is being driven by committed countries like Australia, one top official says. But they still want more from us.

“The middle-sized nations, the Netherlands and the Australias of this world, have to do more to keep this multilateral trading system in place … they have to develop the critical mass to replace the weight of the hegemon,” says Manfred Elsig, a political scientist at Bern University.

Other middle-sized nations will be watching with interest as the Morrison government conducts its audit of multilateral engagement – and hoping Australia doesn’t step away from the table. The beleaguered WTO needs all the help it can get.
description: Donald Trump's trade war with China has dragged the World Trade Organisation into the fray. Can Australia help restore some order?
